profile_json.overview: Fabrinet is a leading provider of advanced optical and electronic manufacturing services, headquartered in the Cayman Islands with primary operations in Thailand. profile_json.thesis: Fabrinet is an indirect but high-conviction play on AI data center optical interconnect buildout. profile_json.overview: Tokyo Electron (TEL) is Japan's largest and the world's third-largest semiconductor equipment maker. Core products span etch systems, CVD/PVD deposition, coater/developers for photolithography, and cleaning systems. TEL is a key beneficiary of leading-edge node transitions and EUV adoption.
profile_json.thesis: TEL is positioned to capture outsized share of the AI-driven capex supercycle. Incremental order momentum is strong, driven by EUV-related deposition layers and advanced packaging demand. China exposure is a risk but manageable at current levels.
key_assumptions: AI/HPC capex cycle sustains through FY2026-27
EUV multi-patterning drives incremental deposition TAM
China revenue remains at ~25% of sales without further restrictions
Etch market share gains continue vs. Lam Research
risk_factors: Escalation of US/Japan China export controls
Cyclical downturn in memory capex
Yen appreciation impacting competitiveness
Customer concentration risk (TSMC, Samsung)

valuation_scenarios.label: Bull Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 30x FY27E EPS on sustained AI capex cycle

valuation_scenarios.label: Bear Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 18x FY26E EPS on China export control escalation

profile_json.valuation_notes: TEL trades at a discount to ASML (35x) and Lam Research (28x) on forward P/E. Discount partly reflects China exposure risk. Upside catalysts: order momentum, China risk de-escalation.

focus: Focus specifically on incremental order growth momentum and new business wins
Monitor China revenue exposure and any regulatory/sanctions developments

companies.name: Advantest

profile_json.overview: Advantest is the world's leading semiconductor test equipment maker, competing primarily with Teradyne. Core products include SoC testers (V93000 platform), memory testers, and SSD test systems. Advantest is the dominant supplier for AI/HPC chip testing.
profile_json.thesis: Advantest is the primary beneficiary of rising test intensity driven by AI chip complexity. The V93000 platform is the industry standard for advanced SoC testing. HBM test demand provides a second structural growth vector. Order momentum is inflecting positively.

HBM test systems become a material revenue contributor
V93000 platform maintains competitive moat vs. Teradyne
Memory test recovery adds to AI-driven SoC test demand
risk_factors: Teradyne competitive response in SoC test

China restrictions impacting memory test shipments
Cyclical memory test demand volatility

companies.name: Disco Corporation
companies.sector: Semiconductor Equipment — Precision Cutting, Grinding, Polishing

profile_json.overview: Disco Corporation is the global leader in precision cutting, grinding, and polishing equipment for semiconductor wafers. Their dicing saws, grinders, and laser processing machines are essential for back-end semiconductor manufacturing. Disco holds dominant market share in dicing (>70% globally).
profile_json.thesis: Disco is a high-quality compounder with dominant market share in precision back-end equipment. The advanced packaging megatrend (chiplets, HBM stacking) should drive structural demand growth. Valuation is full, limiting near-term upside despite strong fundamentals.
key_assumptions: Advanced packaging adoption accelerates (chiplets, 3D stacking)
HBM demand drives incremental dicing and grinding volumes
Pricing power sustained given dominant market position
Consumables revenue provides earnings stability
risk_factors: Valuation premium vulnerable to any growth deceleration
Customer capex delays in packaging equipment
Emerging competition in laser-based dicing
Yen strength impacting overseas competitiveness

valuation_scenarios.label: Bear Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 30x FY26E EPS on packaging capex delay

profile_json.valuation_notes: Disco commands a premium multiple reflecting dominant market position (>70% dicing share) and high recurring consumables revenue. Limited near-term upside at current valuation; catalyst needed.

focus: Monitor advanced packaging order trends, particularly for AI chip dicing and grinding
Track HBM (High Bandwidth Memory) related demand and Disco's positioning
Watch for margin trends and any pricing power signals in precision cutting equipment

profile_json.overview: Lasertec is a Japanese semiconductor equipment company specializing in EUV mask inspection and metrology systems. The company holds a near-monopoly position in actinic (EUV wavelength) mask blank and patterned mask inspection, which is critical for advanced node semiconductor manufacturing at 5nm and below.
profile_json.thesis: Lasertec's EUV mask inspection monopoly is a unique competitive moat, but the stock's premium valuation requires continued order growth to justify. The transition to High-NA EUV presents both opportunity (new tool cycle) and risk (development timeline uncertainty). KLA's competitive entry is an emerging threat.
key_assumptions: EUV mask inspection demand grows with advancing node adoption
High-NA EUV inspection tools are developed and qualified on schedule
Near-monopoly position in actinic inspection is defended against KLA
Customer adoption at TSMC, Samsung, and Intel continues
risk_factors: KLA competitive entry in EUV mask inspection
High-NA EUV inspection development delays or cost overruns
Customer base limited to handful of leading-edge foundries/IDMs
Valuation premium vulnerable to any growth deceleration

valuation_scenarios.label: Bull Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 26x FY27E EPS on High-NA EUV tool cycle win

valuation_scenarios.label: Bear Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 13x FY26E EPS on KLA competitive threat

profile_json.valuation_notes: Lasertec has de-rated significantly from its 2023 highs on KLA competitive concerns and short-seller scrutiny. Current valuation is more reasonable. Key catalyst: High-NA EUV inspection tool qualification. Key risk: KLA gaining share in actinic inspection.

focus: Track EUV mask inspection tool orders and competitive dynamics vs KLA
Monitor High-NA EUV inspection development timeline and customer interest
Watch for customer adoption signals at leading foundries (TSMC, Samsung, Intel)

profile_json.overview: Screen Holdings (formerly Dainippon Screen) is a Japanese semiconductor equipment company specializing in cleaning, coating, and lithography equipment. The company holds a leading market share in single-wafer cleaning systems, which are critical for advanced node manufacturing. Screen also has a display equipment business.
profile_json.thesis: Screen Holdings benefits from the structural trend toward more cleaning steps at advanced nodes. As EUV and multi-patterning increase, the number of cleaning steps per wafer rises significantly, expanding Screen's addressable market. The company's strong position with foundry and memory customers provides order visibility tied to fab construction cycles.
key_assumptions: Semiconductor cleaning equipment orders grow with fab construction spending
Advanced node adoption increases cleaning steps per wafer by 20-30%
New tool qualifications at foundries and memory makers progress

profile_json.overview: Rorze Corporation is a Japanese manufacturer of wafer and panel handling robots used in semiconductor fabs and flat panel display (FPD) manufacturing. profile_json.thesis: Rorze is a niche but high-quality beneficiary of the semiconductor fab construction cycle. The advanced packaging buildout (chiplets, HBM) is an emerging growth vector for panel-level handling systems.

companies.name: Hitachi
companies.sector: Diversified — IT Services, Infrastructure, Industrial Systems

profile_json.overview: Hitachi is a diversified Japanese conglomerate that has undergone a major transformation, divesting low-margin businesses and focusing on digital solutions (Lumada platform), power grid/energy infrastructure, and railway systems. The company is now positioned as a social infrastructure and digital solutions leader.
profile_json.thesis: Hitachi's portfolio transformation is bearing fruit, with the Lumada digital platform driving higher-margin recurring revenue growth. Power grid and energy infrastructure orders are surging globally, and Hitachi (through its GlobalLogic and Hitachi Energy subsidiaries) is well-positioned to capture this demand. Margins have room for further expansion.
key_assumptions: Lumada digital solutions revenue grows 15%+ annually
Power grid/energy infrastructure orders remain strong through 2027
Portfolio restructuring drives operating margin improvement toward 12%+
GlobalLogic integration delivers cross-selling synergies
risk_factors: Conglomerate discount may persist despite restructuring
Energy infrastructure projects carry execution and delivery risk
Yen appreciation negatively impacts overseas earnings translation
IT services segment faces competition from Accenture, TCS

valuation_scenarios.label: Bull Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 28x FY27E EPS on Lumada + energy infrastructure acceleration

valuation_scenarios.label: Base Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 23x FY27E EPS with steady margin expansion

valuation_scenarios.label: Bear Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 17x FY26E EPS on margin expansion stall

profile_json.valuation_notes: Hitachi commands a re-rating premium after successful portfolio transformation. Trades above Japanese conglomerate peers but below global IT services/infrastructure comps. Upside from continued margin expansion and Lumada growth.

focus: Track Lumada digital solutions revenue growth and new customer wins
Monitor power grid and energy infrastructure order trends globally
Watch portfolio restructuring moves and margin improvement trajectory

profile_json.overview: Panasonic Holdings is a diversified Japanese electronics and industrial conglomerate. The company is a major EV battery supplier (primarily to Tesla), and also operates in consumer electronics, housing/building solutions, automotive systems, and industrial automation. Panasonic is undergoing a strategic shift toward energy and industrial solutions.
profile_json.thesis: Panasonic's EV battery business is the key value driver, but execution challenges and Tesla volume volatility create uncertainty. The company's diversified portfolio generates stable cash flow but lacks high-growth catalysts outside batteries. Strategic portfolio changes (potential Panasonic Automotive spinoff) could unlock value.
key_assumptions: EV battery volumes grow with Tesla Gigafactory expansion and new customers
Energy storage (grid-scale batteries) becomes a meaningful revenue contributor
Supply chain/factory automation benefits from reshoring trends
Strategic portfolio rationalization continues with potential segment spin-offs
risk_factors: Tesla battery volume volatility and pricing pressure
Competition from CATL, BYD, and LG in EV batteries
Consumer electronics segment faces secular decline
Conglomerate discount persists despite restructuring

valuation_scenarios.label: Bull Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 17x FY27E EPS on battery growth + portfolio value unlock

valuation_scenarios.label: Bear Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 9x FY26E EPS on Tesla battery order weakness

profile_json.valuation_notes: Panasonic trades at a conglomerate discount with P/B near 1.0x. Battery business value is partially offset by low-growth consumer segments. Catalyst: segment spin-offs or battery business IPO to unlock hidden value.

focus: Track battery business growth including EV and energy storage volumes
Monitor supply chain and factory automation demand trends
Watch for strategic portfolio changes including potential segment spin-offs

profile_json.overview: Samsung Electronics is the world's largest memory chipmaker and a major player in semiconductor foundry, displays (OLED, LCD), and consumer electronics (smartphones, TVs). Memory pricing recovery is supportive, but execution risks in both HBM and foundry create a balanced risk/reward at current levels.

Memory business carries the company while foundry ramps

Consumer electronics segment faces margin pressure

profile_json.overview: Nanya Technology is Taiwan's sole DRAM manufacturer, focused on specialty and consumer DRAM products. The company is significantly smaller than Samsung, SK Hynix, and Micron, and has lagged in technology migration. Nanya primarily serves consumer electronics, PC, and industrial applications rather than the high-growth server/HBM segments.
profile_json.thesis: Nanya is a laggard in the DRAM industry with limited exposure to the AI-driven HBM and server DRAM growth story. The company's technology node trails leaders by 2+ generations, restricting its ability to compete in high-margin advanced DRAM segments. DRAM pricing improvements benefit Nanya, but structural competitiveness issues cap the upside.
key_assumptions: DRAM pricing recovery supports near-term profitability improvement
1A/1B nm technology migration progresses but remains behind leaders
Consumer and specialty DRAM demand provides stable baseline revenue
HBM-related developments remain exploratory with no near-term revenue
risk_factors: Technology gap vs Samsung/SK Hynix/Micron widening
No meaningful HBM capability limits participation in AI demand
DRAM pricing downturn would disproportionately impact margins
Customer base concentrated in lower-value DRAM segments

valuation_scenarios.label: Bull Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 28x FY27E EPS on DRAM super-cycle pricing

profile_json.valuation_notes: Nanya appears overvalued on normalized earnings basis compared to larger DRAM peers. The stock trades above fair value on cyclical recovery hopes, but structural competitive disadvantages limit long-term upside. No HBM exposure is a significant handicap in the AI era.

focus: Monitor DRAM pricing trends and supply/demand balance across memory segments
Track technology migration progress at 1A/1B nm nodes
Watch for any HBM-related developments or strategic partnerships

profile_json.overview: Zhongji Innolight is China's leading optical transceiver company and one of the largest globally, specializing in high-speed optical modules for data center interconnect. The company has emerged as a major supplier of 400G and 800G transceivers to global hyperscalers and is pioneering silicon photonics and LPO (Linear-drive Pluggable Optics) technology.
profile_json.thesis: Zhongji Innolight is at the epicenter of the AI data center optical interconnect buildout. The company's 800G/1.6T product roadmap and silicon photonics capabilities position it as a global leader in next-gen optical modules. Customer diversification across both Chinese and Western hyperscalers provides broad demand exposure, though US entity list risk remains an overhang.
key_assumptions: 800G optical module volumes grow 100%+ in 2025-26 driven by AI data center demand
1.6T product qualification and initial shipments begin in 2026
Silicon photonics and LPO technology leadership is maintained
US entity list risk does not materialize in the near term
risk_factors: US entity list placement would severely restrict access to Western customers
Pricing competition from Eoptolink and other Chinese transceiver makers
Component supply constraints for high-speed lasers and DSPs
Technology transition risk if silicon photonics commoditizes faster than expected

valuation_scenarios.label: Bull Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 18x FY27E EPS on 1.6T ramp + Western customer retention

valuation_scenarios.label: Base Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 13x FY27E EPS with steady 800G volume growth

valuation_scenarios.label: Bear Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 6x FY26E EPS on US entity list placement

profile_json.valuation_notes: Zhongji Innolight trades at a discount to Western optical peers (Coherent at 25x, II-VI at 20x) reflecting China/geopolitical risk premium. The discount is warranted given entity list tail risk but provides exceptional upside if risk does not materialize. Revenue growth trajectory is among the fastest in the semiconductor supply chain.

focus: Track 800G/1.6T optical module shipment volumes and customer diversification
Monitor silicon photonics and LPO technology leadership vs competitors
Watch for US entity list risk developments and export control changes

profile_json.overview: GDS Holdings is one of China's largest carrier-neutral data center operators, providing colocation and managed services to hyperscaler cloud providers, large enterprises, and financial institutions. The company operates over 100 data centers across major Chinese cities and is expanding into Southeast Asia.
profile_json.thesis: GDS is positioned to benefit from China's growing AI and cloud computing demand, which is driving need for additional data center capacity. However, elevated leverage, regulatory uncertainty, and competition from state-backed providers create significant headwinds. The risk/reward is balanced at current levels.
key_assumptions: China AI/cloud demand drives mid-teens annual capacity growth
Utilization rates recover toward 70%+ on new capacity
Pricing stabilizes after recent competitive pressure
Leverage ratio improves through operating cash flow growth
risk_factors: High leverage (net debt/EBITDA >6x) limits financial flexibility
Competition from state-backed China Telecom, China Mobile data centers
Regulatory risk on data sovereignty and cross-border data flows
Power cost inflation and availability constraints

valuation_scenarios.label: Bull Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 18x FY27E EBITDA on China AI demand acceleration

valuation_scenarios.label: Bear Case
valuation_scenarios.methodology: 8x FY26E EBITDA on continued losses and leverage concerns

profile_json.valuation_notes: GDS trades at a steep discount to global data center peers (Equinix at 25x EV/EBITDA) reflecting China risk, leverage, and profitability concerns. Deep value potential if China AI demand accelerates, but high-risk profile limits conviction.

focus: Monitor China data center demand trends from AI and cloud computing adoption
